Issues.Title: `Clipboard.SetDataObject` randomly fails with `CLIPBRD_E_CANT_OPEN`
Issues.Body:
**Problem description:**

The tests that exercise `Clipboard` **randomly** fail on my computer with `CLIPBRD_E_CANT_OPEN` (0x800401D0) in either of these two points:
https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/blob/8aeaa419c478dad316edc7ba4103c8abc2bba40f/src/System.Windows.Forms/src/System/Windows/Forms/Clipboard.cs#L124-L168

I struggle to make any logical conclusions about a cause. There seemed to be other reports from people suffering from similar issues (e.g. https://github.com/ColinDabritz/PoeItemAnalyzer/issues/1, https://stackoverflow.com/q/68666/2338036)

**Expected behavior:**

The code is resilient.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "`Clipboard.SetDataObject` randomly fails with `CLIPBRD_E_CANT_OPEN`" (#3166)

Issues.Title: `Clipboard` API must check for invalid `format`
Issues.Body:
<!-- Read https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/blob/master/Documentation/issue-guide.md -->

* .NET Core Version: current master

* Have you experienced this same bug with .NET Framework?: Yes

**Problem description:**

Observed in https://dev.azure.com/dnceng/public/_build/results?buildId=622784&view=results

```
System.NullReferenceException: Object reference not set to an instance of an object.
   at System.Windows.Forms.DataObject.OleConverter.GetDataFromOleOther(String format) in F:\workspace\_work\1\s\src\System.Windows.Forms\src\System\Windows\Forms\DataObject.cs:line 1435
   at System.Windows.Forms.DataObject.OleConverter.GetDataFromBoundOleDataObject(String format, Boolean& done) in F:\workspace\_work\1\s\src\System.Windows.Forms\src\System\Windows\Forms\DataObject.cs:line 1502
   at System.Windows.Forms.DataObject.OleConverter.GetDataFromBoundOleDataObject(String format, Boolean& done) in F:\workspace\_work\1\s\src\System.Windows.Forms\src\System\Windows\Forms\DataObject.cs:line 1502
   at System.Windows.Forms.DataObject.OleConverter.GetData(String format, Boolean autoConvert) in F:\workspace\_work\1\s\src\System.Windows.Forms\src\System\Windows\Forms\DataObject.cs:line 1677
   at System.Windows.Forms.DataObject.GetData(String format, Boolean autoConvert) in F:\workspace\_work\1\s\src\System.Windows.Forms\src\System\Windows\Forms\DataObject.cs:line 174
   at System.Windows.Forms.DataObject.GetData(String format) in F:\workspace\_work\1\s\src\System.Windows.Forms\src\System\Windows\Forms\DataObject.cs:line 184
   at System.Windows.Forms.Clipboard.GetData(String format) in F:\workspace\_work\1\s\src\System.Windows.Forms\src\System\Windows\Forms\Clipboard.cs:line 322
   at System.Windows.Forms.Tests.ClipboardTests.Clipboard_GetData_InvokeMultipleTimes_Success(String format) in F:\workspace\_work\1\s\src\System.Windows.Forms\tests\UnitTests\System\Windows\Forms\ClipboardTests.cs:line 108
```

Related to #3115.

The following API allow to pass `null`, `string.Empty` or whitespace that all are invalid data formats:
https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/blob/8aeaa419c478dad316edc7ba4103c8abc2bba40f/src/System.Windows.Forms/src/System/Windows/Forms/Clipboard.cs#L317-L326
https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/blob/8aeaa419c478dad316edc7ba4103c8abc2bba40f/src/System.Windows.Forms/src/System/Windows/Forms/Clipboard.cs#L317-L326


**Expected behavior:**

These API must not result in NRE and gracefully handle invalid input. We could throw but this will be breaking.
Instead we should `return null`/`return` respectively.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "`Clipboard` API must check for invalid `format`" (#3163)

Issues.Title: Accessibility: PropertyBrowser sub-level item expanded/collapsed state is not correct
Issues.Body:
* .NET Core Version: 
.Net Core 5.0.100-preview.5.20228.7 from 5.0 master branch + VS2019 with latest core designer

* Have you experienced this same bug with .NET Framework?: 
Yes

**Problem description:**

PropertyBrowser sub-level item accessibility: Inspect shows expanded state when font property is expanded, ExpandCollapse.ExpandCollapseState value is Collapsed(0).

**Minimal repro:**
1.	Create a winforms core application.
2.	Start Inspect and review the Font property in PropertyBrowser using Inspect: expand and collapse the Font property and review its collapsed/expanded state.
[WindowsFormsApp1.zip](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/files/4550427/WindowsFormsApp1.zip)

**Actual behavior:**
Inspect shows collapsed state when font property is expanded.
![Font_inspect_issue](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/45864017/80573753-25c73980-8a33-11ea-8cfb-ec1b0ed8216f.png)

**Expected behavior:**
Inspect should show expanded state when font property is expanded.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Accessibility: PropertyBrowser sub-level item expanded/collapsed state is not correct" (#3162)

Issues.Title: The default title of MsgBox is not correct
Issues.Body:
<!-- Read https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/blob/master/Documentation/issue-guide.md -->

* .NET Core Version: 
5.0.100-preview.3.20216.6

* Have you experienced this same bug with .NET Framework?: 
No

**Problem description:**

The default title is "Microsoft.VisualBasic.Core" instead of the name of the calling assembly.
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/10798596/80573038-daf8f200-8a31-11ea-94aa-875afa229d5f.png)


**Expected behavior:**
The default title should be the name of the calling assembly.
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/10798596/80573409-7e4a0700-8a32-11ea-89ff-88d9d0fe4b20.png)


**Minimal repro:**
Run the following code in a VB winforms project:
```vbnet
MsgBox("Content")
```
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "The default title of MsgBox is not correct" (#3161)

Issues.Title: Code coverage is a bit useless right now, appears broken
Issues.Body:
* .NET Core Version: 
Master

* Have you experienced this same bug with .NET Framework?: 
No

**Problem description:**
We have a lot of errors such as "File not found in report"

E.g. https://codecov.io/gh/dotnet/winforms/pull/3089/changes
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1275900/80572554-618fde00-89f6-11ea-9cd9-9ec66a9dacd2.png)

Also, a lot of PRs say "-36%" coverage, which is obviously wrong

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1275900/80572593-6f456380-89f6-11ea-9702-0b695565d972.png)
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Code coverage is a bit useless right now, appears broken" (#3160)

Issues.Title: Accessibility: Narrator cannot announce PropertyBrowser top-level and sub-level items expanded/collapsed state
Issues.Body:
* .NET Core Version: 
.Net Core 5.0.100-preview.5.20228.7 from 5.0 master branch + VS2019 with latest core designer

* Have you experienced this same bug with .NET Framework?: 
Yes

**Problem description:**

PropertyBrowser top-level and sub-level items accessibility: Narrator cannot announce top-level and sub-level items expanded/collapsed state.

**Minimal repro:**
1.	Create a winforms core application.
2.	Start Narrator and focus on Font and Accessibility property in property browser window, observe Narrator behavior.
[WindowsFormsApp1.zip](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/files/4550312/WindowsFormsApp1.zip)

**Actual behavior:**
Narrator cannot announce Font and Accessibility property expanded/collapsed state.
![Narrator_not_read_expand_collapsed](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/45864017/80571756-bac83380-8a2f-11ea-90b9-ba07637efd70.gif)

**Expected behavior:**
Narrator should announce Font and Accessibility property expanded/collapsed state correctly.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Accessibility: Narrator cannot announce PropertyBrowser top-level and sub-level items expanded/collapsed state" (#3159)

Issues.Title: Update Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.PublicApiAnalyzers
Issues.Body:
Taking the fix from https://github.com/dotnet/roslyn-analyzers/pull/3553

Issues.Title: Implement Collapsible/Collapsed for ListViewGroup
Issues.Body:
<!-- Please read CONTRIBUTING.md before submitting a pull request -->

Fixes #3067 


## Proposed changes

- Add Collapsible/Collapsed API to `ListViewGroup`

<!-- We are in TELL-MODE the following section must be completed -->

## Customer Impact

- Customers will have the ability to make their ListViewGroups collapsible and collapse/expand items in the group

<!-- end TELL-MODE -->


## Screenshots <!-- Remove this section if PR does not change UI -->

### Before

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/30007367/80523089-62673800-8942-11ea-92a6-4b0e887ef200.png)

<!-- TODO -->

### After

![collapse2](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/30007367/80524343-4e243a80-8944-11ea-8749-4529c305ae1c.gif)
<!-- TODO -->


## Test methodology <!-- How did you ensure quality? -->

- Manual testing
- Unit testing

## TODOs  <!-- Remove this section if PR does not change UI -->

- [ ]  Accessibility Testing
- [ ]  Add more tests

<!--
     Microsoft prioritizes making our products accessible. 
     WinForms has a key role in allowing developers to create accessible apps. 
     
     When submitting a change which impacts UI in any way, including adding new UI or
     modifying existing controls the developer needs to run the Accessibility Insights
     tool (https://accessibilityinsights.io/) and verify that there are no changes or
     regressions. 
     
     The developer should run the Fast Pass over the impacted control(s) and provide
     a snapshot of the passing results along with before/after snapshots of the UI.
     More info: (https://accessibilityinsights.io/docs/en/web/getstarted/fastpass)
  -->

## Notes
- Currently `Collapsed` is no-op if `Collapsible = false`. If user tries to set `Collapsed = true` when `Collapsible = false`, `Collapsed` remains `false`
- The user can either collapse item(s) through single click on chevron or double click on group header

I'm wondering if these behaviors are fine. Alternatively we could uphold the user's setting of `Collapsed` regardless if `Collapsible` is true/false, but not visually show this state until `Collapsible = true`

###### Microsoft Reviewers: [Open in CodeFlow](http://wpcp.azurewebsites.net/CodeFlowProtocolProxy2.php?pullrequest=https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/pull/3155)
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "Implement Collapsible/Collapsed for ListViewGroup" (#3155)

Issues.Title: The text and icon of tooltip are not displayed on the same horizontal line
Issues.Body:
<!-- Read https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/blob/master/Documentation/issue-guide.md -->

* .NET Core Version: 
5.0.100-preview.5.20227.13

* Have you experienced this same bug with .NET Framework?: 
Yes

**Problem description:**
The text and icon of tooltip are not displayed on the same horizontal line.
![Coe](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/62929087/80458532-838c5080-8963-11ea-8e64-5c8db719e9b5.png)

**Expected behavior:**
The text and icon of tooltip should be displayed on the same horizontal line.

**Minimal repro:**
1. Create a winforms core project.
2. Add a button and a tooltip controls to form designer.
3. Set the button's ToolTip on toolTip1 as: hello, this is button1.
4. Set the tooltip's ToolTipIcon as **Info**.
5. Run the core project.
6. Focus on the button using mouse to see the tooltip of button.

Or
1. Run the attached project. 
[TooltipApp.zip](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/files/4543969/TooltipApp.zip)
2. Focus on the button using mouse to see the tooltip of button.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "The text and icon of tooltip are not displayed on the same horizontal line" (#3153)

Issues.Title: The up and down arrows are not disabled when selecting the first or the last member in Images Collection Editor
Issues.Body:
<!-- Read https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/blob/master/Documentation/issue-guide.md -->

* .NET Core Version: 
5.0.100-preview.5.20227.13

* Have you experienced this same bug with .NET Framework?: 
Yes

**Problem description:**
The up and down arrows are not disabled when selecting the first or the last member.
![Core](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/62929087/80453247-76b72f00-895a-11ea-8db8-f2a9fa4a5428.png)

**Expected behavior:**
The up arrow should be disabled when selecting the first member.
The down arrow should be disabled when selecting the last member.
![Designer](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/62929087/80453850-a3b81180-895b-11ea-94a6-e5382943007d.png)

**More info:**
1. This issue also can reproduce with .Net Core 3.1.
2. This issue also can reproduce for MonthCalndar/ListView/TabControl/treeView controls.

**Minimal repro:**
1. Create a winforms core project.
2. Add a propertyGrid and a ImageList controls to form designer.
3. Add this code in the construction method of form: propertyGrid1.SelectedObject = imageList1;
4. Run the core project.
5. Find the **Images** property of ImageList, click the Browser button to show the Images Collection Editor.
6. Click the Add button to add 4 images in it, then select the last member.
7. Observe the down arrows on the right of the images.

Or
1. Run the attached project.
[TestApp.zip](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/files/4543689/TestApp.zip)
2. Do the above step 5-7.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "The up and down arrows are not disabled when selecting the first or the last member in Images Collection Editor" (#3152)

Issues.Title: SetLastError=true missing on some extern declarations
Issues.Body:
There are quite a lot of extern declarations for Win32 API in the winforms repo that don't use SetLastError=true even though the docs indicate the API sets an error retrievable with GetLastError. (I attached an approximate list of some). 

Of course in many, possibly all of those cases the code never calls `Marshal.GetLastWin32Error()` nor throws `Win32Exception` so it doesn't matter. I am not sure whether to interpret [our guidance](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/dotnet/standard/native-interop/best-practices#dllimport-attribute-settings)  to mean "apply SetLastError=true whenever the API is documented to set last error" or "apply SetLastError=true whenever the API sets last error and you also intend to retrieve it". The latter saves the infrastructure calling GetLastError() for you unnecessarily, but that is presumably very fast - and avoids the possibility of reading some previous API's error because you hadn't updated the extern declaration.

@AaronRobinsonMSFT @JeremyKuhne  ? 

[list.txt](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/files/4543243/list.txt)
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "SetLastError=true missing on some extern declarations" (#3151)

Issues.Title: Tests fail running out of handles
Issues.Body:
**Problem description:**

Having moved to a different pool (#3105), and (temporarily) disabled tests that relied on `RemoteExecutor` (#3116), we are now observing new build failures with the following:
```
    System.Windows.Forms.Tests.ProfessionalColorTableTests.ProfessionalColorTable_Properties_Get_ReturnsExpected(factory: Func`2 { Method = System.Drawing.Color <Properties_TestData>b__1_49(System.Windows.Forms.ProfessionalColorTable), Target = <>c { } }) [FAIL]
      System.Runtime.InteropServices.COMException : The current process has used all of its system allowance of handles for Window Manager objects. (0x80070486)
      Stack Trace:
           at System.Threading.Monitor.ReliableEnter(Object obj, Boolean& lockTaken)
           at System.Threading.Monitor.Enter(Object obj, Boolean& lockTaken)
        /_/src/System.Windows.Forms/src/System/Windows/Forms/NativeWindow.cs(423,0): at System.Windows.Forms.NativeWindow.CreateHandle(CreateParams cp)
        .....
        --- End of stack trace from previous location ---

    System.Windows.Forms.Tests.ScrollableControlTests.ScrollableControl_SetAutoScrollMargin_InvokeWithHandle_Success(autoScroll: False, width: 1, height: 2, expectedAutoScrollMargin: {Width=1, Height=2}, expectedLayoutCallCount: 0) [FAIL]
      System.ComponentModel.Win32Exception : Error creating window handle.
      Stack Trace:
        /_/src/System.Windows.Forms/src/System/Windows/Forms/NativeWindow.cs(491,0): at System.Windows.Forms.NativeWindow.CreateHandle(CreateParams cp)
        .....

    System.Windows.Forms.Tests.MonthCalendarTests.MonthCalendar_SelectionRange_SetWithHandle_GetReturnsExpected(value: SelectionRange: Start: 4/28/2020 12:00:00 AM, End: 4/28/2020 12:00:00 AM, expectedSelectionStart: 2020-04-28T00:00:00.0000000+00:00, expectedSelectionEnd: 2020-04-28T00:00:00.0000000+00:00) [FAIL]
      System.ComponentModel.Win32Exception : Error creating window handle.
      Stack Trace:
        /_/src/System.Windows.Forms/src/System/Windows/Forms/NativeWindow.cs(491,0): at System.Windows.Forms.NativeWindow.CreateHandle(CreateParams cp)
        ...
```

Here's one of examples: https://dev.azure.com/dnceng/public/_build/results?buildId=620251&view=results, build log: [System.Windows.Forms.Tests_netcoreapp5.0_x64 (20).log](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/files/4542863/System.Windows.Forms.Tests_netcoreapp5.0_x64.20.log)
There is no code change, only an MD file. Debug build has succeeded, whilst Release has failed.

**Expected behavior:**

Tests pass without running out of handles.

**Minimal repro:**

N/A, builds fail intermittently.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Tests fail running out of handles" (#3150)

Issues.Title: [loc][Query][winforms] Localizability of strings
Issues.Body:
Hi,
please help localization team to answer question from translator.
In case translator is not sure about context/meaning/localizability of string we raise a question to Core team.
Thanks in advance for the reply


Id | File Name Live Page Extended | String Resource ID | Full Source String | Query: | Answer:
-- | -- | -- | -- | -- | --
49,502 | System.Windows.Forms\src\Resources\xlf\SR.xlf | 0;   "TaskDialogCannotUpdateAfterNavigation" | Cannot manipulate the task   dialog immediately after navigating it. Please wait for the {0} event of the   next page to occur. | Could you please explain what   exactly you mean by 'navigating a dialog'? How is it different from   manipulating a dialog? Normally we'd understand 'to navigate' to mean when   the user is working with the dialog, clicking buttons etc. But here the   meaning is apparently very different.          Affected ResourceIDs:     0; "TaskDialogCannotNavigateClosedDialog"     0; "TaskDialogCannotNavigateWithinNavigationEventHandler"     0; "TaskDialogCannotNavigateWithinRadioButtonCheckedChanged"     0; "TaskDialogCannotNavigateWithoutDialog"     0; "TaskDialogCannotUpdateAfterNavigation"     0; "TaskDialogNavigationNotCompleted" |  
49,503 | System.Windows.Forms\src\Resources\xlf\SR.xlf | 0;   "TaskDialogCollectionAlreadyBound" | One of the collections of this   {0} is already bound to a {1} instance. | Please provide the meaning of   placeholder {0} in the below ResourceIDs:          0; "TaskDialogCollectionAlreadyBound"     One of the collections of this {0} is already bound to a {1}   instance.          0; "TaskDialogControlAlreadyBound"     One of the controls of this {0} is already bound to a {1} instance. |  
49,513 | System.Windows.Forms\src\Resources\xlf\SR.xlf | 0;   "TaskDialogCollectionAlreadyBound" | One of the collections of this   {0} is already bound to a {1} instance. | Please confirm that placeholder   0 is referred to task dialog |
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "[loc][Query][winforms] Localizability of strings" (#3146)

Issues.Title: An error dialog pops up after clicking Add button in DataGridViewColumn Collection Editor
Issues.Body:
<!-- Read https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/blob/master/Documentation/issue-guide.md -->

* .NET Core Version: 
5.0.100-preview.5.20226.6
<!-- e.g. 3.0 Preview1, or daily build number, use `dotnet --info` -->

* Have you experienced this same bug with .NET Framework?: 
No
<!-- Yes / No -->

**Problem description:**
An error dialog is occurring after clicking the Add button.
![Error](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/18568603/80338522-1a3b0d80-888f-11ea-90a4-947014b9608d.png)
<!--
    Describe the current behavior, what is wrong or not working as expected.
    Provide as much information as possible, including callstack for crashes/exceptions, screenshots or animations.
  -->
**Expected behavior:**
The columns can be added successfully without any error/warning popping up.

**More info:**
This issue also can reproduce with .Net Core 3.1.

**Minimal repro:**
1.	Create a winforms core project.
2.	Add a propertyGrid control to form.
3.	Add a DataGridView control to form.
4.	Add this code in form initializeComponent part: propertyGrid1.SelectedObject = dataGridView1;
5.	Find the Columns property of DataGridView, click the Browser button to show the DataGridViewColumn Collection Editor.
6.	Click the Add button.

Or 
1.	Run the attached project.
[DataGridViewCell.zip](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/files/4537739/DataGridViewCell.zip)
2.	Run it, and do the above step 5-6.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "An error dialog pops up after clicking Add button in DataGridViewColumn Collection Editor" (#3143)

Issues.Title: An error dialog pops up after clicking Add button in ToolStripItem Collection Editor
Issues.Body:
<!-- Read https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/blob/master/Documentation/issue-guide.md -->

* .NET Core Version: 
5.0.100-preview.5.20226.6
<!-- e.g. 3.0 Preview1, or daily build number, use `dotnet --info` -->

* Have you experienced this same bug with .NET Framework?: 
No
<!-- Yes / No -->

**Problem description:**
An error dialog is occurring after clicking the Add button.
![Error](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/18568603/80338361-badcfd80-888e-11ea-9040-8715186848eb.png)

<!--
    Describe the current behavior, what is wrong or not working as expected.
    Provide as much information as possible, including callstack for crashes/exceptions, screenshots or animations.
  -->


**Expected behavior:**
The items can be added successfully without any error/warning popping up.

**More info:**

1. This issue also can reproduce with BindingNavigator/ContextMenuStrip/MenuStrip/StatusStrip/ToolStrip controls
2. This issue also can reproduce with .Net Core 3.1.

**Minimal repro:**
1.	Create a winforms core project.
2.	Add a propertyGrid control to form.
3.	Add a MenuStrip control to form.
4.	Add this code in form initializeComponent part: propertyGrid1.SelectedObject = menuStrip1;
5.	Find the Items property of MenuStrip, click the Browser button to show the ToolStripItem Collection Editor.
6.	Click the Add button.

Or 
1.	Run the attached project.
[System.ToolStripItem.zip](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/files/4537729/System.ToolStripItem.zip)
2.	Run it, and do the above step 5-6.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "An error dialog pops up after clicking Add button in ToolStripItem Collection Editor" (#3142)

Issues.Title: Fix RichTextBox Rtf encoding
Issues.Body:
Fixes #3032

Cherry-picked from 9729e9cd6d4289150969bc3b481518b71f37a086

<!-- Please read CONTRIBUTING.md before submitting a pull request -->


## Proposed changes

- .NET Core Encoding.Default gets UTF-8, not the default code page. Change our code to get the code page as we're sending data to the control as ASCII.

<!-- We are in TELL-MODE the following section must be completed -->

## Customer Impact

- Customers who may have relied on the original behaviour of RTB to have ASCII as the default code page will be able to continue porting their apps to .NET Core 3.1.

## Regression? 

- Yes

## Risk

- Limited to RTB use in .NET Core 3.1

<!-- end TELL-MODE -->


## Screenshots <!-- Remove this section if PR does not change UI -->

After assigning to `richTextBox.Rtf` some rtf code with nonbreaking space (160 char code), RichTextBox converts it to `\'c2\~` insted of `\~`.
![Snipaste_2020-04-02_15-01-27](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/17767561/78247868-4bc0f300-74f4-11ea-9805-b74f9484ebcc.png)





###### Microsoft Reviewers: [Open in CodeFlow](http://wpcp.azurewebsites.net/CodeFlowProtocolProxy2.php?pullrequest=https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/pull/3141)
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "Fix RichTextBox Rtf encoding" (#3141)

Issues.Title: Fixing Issue 3124 property grid view list box accessibility issues
Issues.Body:
<!-- Please read CONTRIBUTING.md before submitting a pull request -->

Fixes #3124


## Proposed changes

- Reworking PropertyGridView ListBox AccessibleObject implementation to inherit from standalone ListBox AccessibleObject.
- Adding safer calls to system IAccessible object (COM) to prevent unexpected exceptions while accessing native accessibility when this is not found.
- Improving accessibility navigation to ListBox within the PropertyGrid to prevent navigating to the list when this is hidden.

<!-- We are in TELL-MODE the following section must be completed -->

## Customer Impact

- Customers will not experience unexpected errors when working with PropertyGridView with assist of Accessibility client apps.
- Customers will be able to navigate correctly thru the list of PropertyGridView properties and distinct Properties' lists of available options.

## Regression? 

- No

## Risk

- Minimal

<!-- end TELL-MODE -->


## Screenshots <!-- Remove this section if PR does not change UI -->

### Before
![Before](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/23213980/80238646-74598a00-8667-11ea-87ca-88b7205bd763.gif)

### After
![After](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/23213980/80238676-7d4a5b80-8667-11ea-930e-8b0c161cb869.png)

## Test methodology <!-- How did you ensure quality? -->

- Manual testing.
- Unit testing.
- Automation test.

## Accessibility testing  <!-- Remove this section if PR does not change UI -->

<!--
     Microsoft prioritizes making our products accessible. 
     WinForms has a key role in allowing developers to create accessible apps. 
     
     When submitting a change which impacts UI in any way, including adding new UI or
     modifying existing controls the developer needs to run the Accessibility Insights
     tool (https://accessibilityinsights.io/) and verify that there are no changes or
     regressions. 
     
     The developer should run the Fast Pass over the impacted control(s) and provide
     a snapshot of the passing results along with before/after snapshots of the UI.
     More info: (https://accessibilityinsights.io/docs/en/web/getstarted/fastpass)
  -->


 

## Test environment(s) <!-- Remove any that don't apply -->

<!-- use `dotnet --info` -->
.NET Core SDK (reflecting any global.json):
 Version:   5.0.100-alpha.1.20073.10
 Commit:    29f4d693a9

Runtime Environment:
 OS Name:     Windows
 OS Version:  10.0.18363
 OS Platform: Windows
 RID:         win10-x64
 Base Path:   C:\Program Files\dotnet\sdk\5.0.100-alpha1-05536\

Host (useful for support):
  Version: 5.0.0-alpha.1.20072.3
  Commit:  c3dc1fdfdc

<!-- Mention language, UI scaling, or anything else that might be relevant -->
